Chicago PrE-Learning is an online education platform for early learners (from birth to age 5) to easily continue their education outside of the classroom and from the comfort of their home. PrE-Learning provides children with a safe and simple way to adjust to remote learning without missing a beat. There are plenty of activities for early learners of all levels to enjoy. Use Chicago PrE-Learning to learn new fun activities, access e-learning tools, and resources and get the support you need to guide your children through remote learning.

Art is a core component of culture, and culture binds us together. So when times are divisive, it’s even more important to create and share the products we make. That’s why the theme of our 7th annual Teen Winter Challenge is Art to Unite!

If you’re a Chicago high schooler between ages 13 to 19, submit your recently created art to our Teen Winter Challenge using the form below. Submissions that demonstrate talent, creativity and originality will be eligible for prizes and recognition. Plus, every applicant will have one work printed in the 7th annual Teen Winter Challenge catalog, which will be added to the YOUmedia Zine collection.

Submission Guidelines

  • Who: High school students between ages 13 to 19 who live in Chicago.
  • What: Submit a portfolio of 1 to 3 original works in a digital format along with an artist statement.
  • When: Submit your works between now and March 1, 2022.
  • Where: The form below!

Portfolio submissions must contain 1 to 3 original creative works from the past year and can represent a variety of mediums including drawing, painting, sculpture, film, photography, fashion, etc.

Your artist statement is meant to give insight into both you and your work in 250 words or less. Some helpful prompts:

  • Discuss the meaning/intention behind your artistic choices and the overall piece
  • Write about your prior experiences as an artist and your goals for the future

Evaluation process: Submissions will be judged by a panel of Chicago Public Library staff and guest judges from the Chicago arts community. Evaluation will be based on the clarity of your artist statement, the passion to create and the artistic merit of the piece(s).

Every applicant will have one work printed in our Teen Winter Challenge catalog. Of these works, up to 12 exceptional pieces will receive one of the following prizes:

Senior Achievement Award
Open to high school seniors.

  • Grand prize: $150 gift card
  • First and second runners-up: $100 gift card
  • Honorable mentions (3): $50 gift card

Young Artist Award
Open to high school freshmen, sophomores and juniors.

  • Grand prize: $100 gift card
  • First and second runners-up: $50 gift card
  • Honorable mentions (3): $25 gift card

program_name: Visual Arts Classes for Middle School Students
description: This course is an introduction to visual arts and craft “DIY” projects. Participants will explore a variety of wet and dry materials and create group and individual projects. Youth will develop or enhance drawing and painting skills ad well as explore a variety of art mediums. Participants will be challenged to incorporate ideas about their community into their art as well as self-expression to develop cultural awareness and self-awareness.

Join us on Saturdays from 11:30 am - 12:30 pm!

program_name: Which Planet is the Flattest At-Home Activity
description: What shape are the planets? It’s likely not what you think. In this activity, you will create your own model of a rotating planet and make some observations. Then, determine which planet is indeed the flattest.

Kids, pick up your Time Capsule kit today at a nearby Chicago Public Library branch!

It’s as simple as 1, 2, 3.

1. Grab a Time Capsule kit at the library.

What’s a Time Capsule you ask? A Time Capsule is a container of important stories from the present that gets sealed or buried for discovery in the future.

2. Make your own Time Capsule at home.

You lived through so much change this year and you were so brave! You want to hear your story. Follow the instructions in your kit to make your own Time Capsule.

3. Bring your Time Capsule back to the library.

Once you make your Time Capsule with all the fun stuff in the kit, return it to the library. You will receive a special button that tells all of Chicago you made a special Time Capsule.

program_name: Voices for Justice: Author Qian Julie Wang
description: Chicago Public Library is pleased to welcome author Qian Julie Wang as part of our Voices for Justice speaker series, and in celebration of Asian American Pacific Islander Month. She is the author of Beautiful Country, a bestselling memoir on her life growing up as an undocumented child in the richest country in the world. She will be in conversation with journalist Monica Eng. Qian Julie Wang is a litigator and the author of Beautiful Country. Beautiful Country was released in 2021 and became an instant New York Times bestseller. Lauded as an Òessential book for our timesÓ and named one of the New York Times Book ReviewÕs Notable Books of 2021, Beautiful Country is a poignant and heartrending literary memoir that intimately retraces Qian JulieÕs childhood footsteps where at age seven, she moved from China to Brooklyn, New York with her parents, and overnight went from being the daughter of professors to being deemed Òillegal.Ó With an open heart and a strong passion for advocacy and bringing awareness to marginalized communities, she uses her unique gift for storytelling to transcend the business, legal, political, and literary worlds and focus on the humanity at the heart of these issues.Monica Eng is a reporter for Axios Chicago where she reports on food, health, cultural, politics, environmental issues and more. Before coming to Axios in 2021, she worked at WBEZ, the Sun Times and the Chicago Tribune where she spent 16 years editing and reporting on food, culture and health. Monica has won multiple writing awards and been nominated for the James Beard Award five times. Monica is a fourth generation Chicagoan whose great grandfather came to Chicago from China in 1911. Her children are fourth generation Chicago Public School graduates.This program is made possible thanks to generous support from the Chicago Public Library Foundation. For more information on the Foundation, visit cplfoundation.org.Questions for the speaker? Reach out to us at adultservices@chipublib.orgThe book can also be purchased online. How to Attend:This event will take place live on CPL's YouTube channel and CPL's Facebook page. You'll be able to ask questions during the event as well! Can't make it to the live stream? We'll archive the video on YouTube to watch later.AccessibilityAutomatic captioning is available via Facebook and YouTube's closed captioning setting. Need ASL interpretation or other accommodations for this event? Please call (312) 747-4015. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

program_name: Science Fiction & Fantasy Book Group: Dawn by Octavia E. Butler
description: All are welcome to join a book discussion of Octavia E. Butler's Dawn (1987).ÒWhen Lilith Iyapo wakes from a deep sleep, she finds herself aboard a vast spaceship, haunted by confused memories of a nuclear war that ravaged the world. She discovers that she is being held by the Oankali, a seemingly benevolent alien race that intervened in the human raceÕs extinction, rescuing the survivors from their ruined planet and placing them in a coma-like sleep for centuries. Now the restored Earth is ready for inhabitants, and the Oankali want Lilith to help awaken the rest of the survivors and rebuild humankind. But the Oankali have needs of their ownÉ and salvation comes at a price. Soon Lilith must choose how much of humanity she is willing to sacrifice for the future of her race.Ó- from Grand Central PublishingHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. MY SO is a STEM program that is available to all middle and high school students who love STEM and want to stay engaged in learning - at home, at school, or after school. The Chicago Center for Arts and Technology (CHICAT) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit dedicated to the support of Chicago’s North Lawndale, Pilsen, and Little Village neighborhoods. It is a state -of-the-art community serving organization that offers life-changing learning and career opportunities for young people and adults. CHICAT educates and inspires youth through free arts and technology programs and empowers adults through free career training programs that help them find sustainable employment. CHICAT elevates the talents of the community through transformative arts studios, industry -driven vocational training, and a beautiful space to unify the communities we serve. CHICAT believes that everyone deserves access to the resources necessary to provide a better quality of life, including socioeconomic stability, professional development, and gainful employment.

As a summer fellow, you will teach students in their respective subjects and support the lead artist in curriculum building and classroom management. The fellow plays a crucial role in teaching students the different equipment and software they will use in class and provide a safe, supportive, and interactive program while ensuring the safety and security of all program participants.

  • Job Description:
    In conjunction with the arts instructors, 1) support curriculum development and implementation for the six-week high school summer Design, Digital, and Makers arts courses, 2) assist students during classes to complete assignments and projects, 3) assists in the preparation and installation of exhibits, receptions, workshops, and special projects , 4) participates in regular CHICAT Youth Arts team meetings and trainings, 5) help manage the arts lab by conducting inventory, preparing supply orders, etc., and 6) other duties as assigned.
  • Job Term: June 28, 2021 through August 20, 2021 on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays under the direct guidance of arts lab instructor but reporting to the Interim Director of Youth Arts.
  • Work Days/Hours: 12-5 , Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays onsite at CHICAT
  • Fellowship Award/Stipend: $1,500
  • May apply for one of the three Arts Labs;o DesignLab:Mustbefamiliarwithfashiondesign,drawing,fashionhistory,apparel construction, Special FX, Cosplay props, fashion trends, and color theory.o 3DMakersLab: Mustbefamiliarelectronics,circuitboards,andprogrammingLED lights.o DigitalLab:MustbefamiliarwithAdobeSuite,videoproduction,andgraphicdesign.

• How to apply: Submit resume and cover letter indicating which lab applying for by June 11. Background checks

If the above responsibilities are completed satisfactory and as agreed, as part of this opportunity, you will have:

• •

• •

•

Scheduled access to work in the arts lab under the supervision of the instructor when the lab is open and available in order to produce personal artwork.
Use of arts supplies and available equipment in the lab with approval by the Interim Youth Arts Director. You may also request the purchase of some additional supplies, if needed, to support personal art projects. All requests must be submitted to the Interim Director of Youth Arts for pre-approval.

Mentorship meetings with CHICAT staff to support professional growth
Opportunity to exhibit approved artwork in the CHICAT gallery for a minimum of one week by October 1, 2021.
Have your profile included on the CHICAT website, social media, and/or other communications .

To Apply:

Send your resume and art portfolio (if you have one) via email to Roxanne Walton at roxanne@chicat.org. Any questions, please contact Roxanne at 312-733-1701.

description: Canva is a robust cloud-based digital design tool that can be used to make anything from posts for social media to event flyers, and even stylized resumes.  It is a great resource if you are interested in dipping your toes into digital design in a user-friendly way.  This short class will show how to navigate Canva and get started with different features and format types.  We will complete a follow-along tour followed with independent work time at the end if you'd like to test your new skills and get feedback and tips.  If you would like to follow along, create an account on Canva.com before this session.  There is a paid version, but the free version is amazing and has plenty of options for beginners to more advanced users.This event is hosted by Rachael from the Richard M. Daley Branch who enjoys digital design and exploring open source tools like Canva.How To Attend:This event takes place on Zoom. For millennia tattooing has served as a unique art form with many intimate and social purposes across the world. But why do we tattoo, scar, or ink our skin? In this workshop series we will engage global tattoo traditions and histories spanning from ancient civilizations to present day meanings of tribal tattooing, and more.  From tattoo folk art influences in the contemporary art world to cultural significances and stereotypes about prison and gang culture tattoos, we will explore our preconceptions about tattoo art and use these comparisons to talk about our own identities, body image, and colonial legacies leading to modern day misconceptions about race.  Throughout this monthly workshop series we will delve into tattoo techniques, styles, and symbols as we craft, sketch, and draw our own tattoo designs. This is the first program for Tattoos & Tribes, a virtual series by Jose Luis Benavides, YOUmedia teen associate at Back of the Yards Branch. How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register by 10 a.m. the day before the event. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. Only one registration per household is necessary. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines. This event uses a third-party website and may be hosted by an organization CPL has partnered with. program_name: Health Professions Recruitment and Exposure Program (HPREP)
description: HPREP is a five-week educational and exposure program for high school students of diverse backgrounds. Hosted by the Feinberg Office of Diversity and Inclusion, the program's goal is to provide students first-hand exposure to the Feinberg medical curriculum, career options in healthcare, tools for academic success, and opportunities to interact with current medical students, physicians, nurses, and other healthcare professionals. Two students groups, the Student National Medical Association (SNMA) and the Latino Medical Student Association (LMSA) spearhead the program at Feinberg.

program_name: Women in Science and Engineering Camps
description: The Women in Engineering Summer Program (WIESP), sponsored by Knowles Corporation, is a free, 4-week, non-residential program that offers high school students an unparalleled opportunity to learn more about engineering through hands-on projects and field trips. Participants will also have an opportunity to work with world-renowned professors, meet COE students, make new friends, and earn a stipend upon successful completion of the program!

program_name: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone Book Club - Read Aloud and Activities
description:
In this class, students will join their peers and their teacher for a fun, lively discussion of the Harry Potter books. Students will have fun talking about their favorite characters and moment. They will also explore the themes and what we can learn from these stories. Students will take turns reading the chapters aloud to the class. I will provide students with a few questions each week to think about as they do that week's reading.

By participating in this class, students will learn how to interact with their peers, how to discuss what they are reading, and how to agree and disagree respectfully when opinions differ. My goal as a teacher is to be a guide. I will facilitate discussions and encourage students to both give voice to their thoughts and be kind to others as they voice their own. Each lesson will be highly interactive. Students should be prepared to participate in discussions during each meeting. No prior knowledge or experience is required for this class. Students only need to bring a love for reading and discussion!

Students will need to have access to the Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone.

Accommodations and Modifications available for English Language Learners (ELL/ESL), learners with disabilities, and gifted children-

-Think time

-Prompts: verbal, gestural, visual, model

-Shorten assignments

-Check for understanding by having the student restate or paraphrase information

-Obtain students attention before speaking

-Provide directions in a variety of modalities

-Calculation devices

-Graphic organizer

-Reduce distractions to the student

-100's number table

-Multiplication Table

-Calculator

-Focus on mastery of more functional math concepts

-Grade spelling separately from content

-Provide a vocabulary list with definitions

-Provide alternative books with similar concepts but an easier reading level

-Provide feedback based on individual progress or effort

-Provide the first letter of the missing word

-Shorten spelling tests to focus on mastering the most functional words

Please let me know if your learner has a learning plan and any other special requests.

program_name: Jumpin' Jambalaya: A Tasty Mix of Stories with Kucha and Baba Tony
description: Join staff from Hall Branch for this engaging storytelling program.Kucha and Baba Tony weave a rich tapestry of fanciful folktales, frolicking fables and dialect into their performance art. This unique presentation is accompanied by drumming and shekere playing (the shekere is an African instrument made of a beaded gourd), enhanced by audience participation, which involves singing, learning and lots of fun. Are you, a family member or friend experiencing difficulty reading standard printed books and magazines?The Assistive Resources and Talking Book Center provides access to tens of thousands of fiction and non-fiction titles in audio book format for people of all ages who have difficulty using or reading regular print. Members may receive materials in two ways: by download to a personal device through our popular mobile app or by first class mail. In either case, there is no charge. Our collection also includes braille books, magazines and content in 70 world languages. This workshop will explain how to register for service and explore the vast collection that is available to members. How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Anne Shimojima's Sakura Tales; Stories from Japan
description: Anne Shimojima, a third generation Japanese American, has been sharing traditional Japanese folk tales for over thirty years. We invite you to listen to eleven of these - Sakura Tales; Stories from Japan - in an hour long program for teens and adults hosted by the Asian American and Pacific Islander Committee. Sakura is the Japanese word for cherry blossom.Folk tales are often forgotten as we grow older. Revisiting and remembering them is a gateway to novel and more enriching experiences and is a beautiful way to commemorate and rekindle the past. By telling the Sakura Tales, Shimojima can feel the connection to her great-grandparents' silkworm farm in Nagano-ken, and she honors the memory of her immigrant grandparents, whose spirit of gaman (perseverance) helped them survive life in a new land. Anne became a professional storyteller in 1982. She taught graduate courses in storytelling for National-Louis University and for eight years served on the board of the Wild Onion Storytelling Festival in Chicago. She is a member of the National Storytelling Network, the Northlands Storytelling Network, and Illinois Storytelling, Inc.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. YouÕll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. This Pyramid Escape Room lesson is a critical thinking Minecraft-themed course for students aged 6-10. In this course, students will practice their observation, critical thinking, and reasoning and problem solving skills. The Matchstick Pattern game will help students improve their critical thinking skills; Spot the Difference will help students practice their observational skills; The Collection Game gives students a sense of fulfillment as they complete tasks.

The various activities and games within this lesson not only allow students to practice their critical, observational, and critical and problem solving skills, but they also give students an immersive experience of a Minecraft adventure.

Please join us a lively discussion of the film Casablanca."Of all the gin joints in all the towns in all the world, she walks into mine." Academy Award winners Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman light up the screen in one of the most enduring romances in movie history--Casablanca. Rick Blaine (Bogart--The African Queen, The Caine Mutiny) owns a nightclub in Vichy-controlled Casablanca, frequented by refugees desperate to escape German domination. Despite the ever-present human misery, Rick manages to remain uninvolved in World War II now raging across Europe and Northern Africa. But all that changes when Ilsa Lund (Bergman--Gaslight, Notorious) walks through the front door of Rick's club--Rick must now choose between a life with the woman he loves and becoming the hero that both she and the world need.Copies of the book are available through our website or by calling your local branch. There will be copies held at the Clearing Branch Library behind the circulation desk. If you have not seen the film, stop by the library for a film screening.How to AttendThe discussion will take place online using Zoom. program_name: Stories of Peace, Power and Joy with Mama Edie
description: Join staff from Jeffery Manor Branch as they host this online storytelling program. Fun, frolicky or somber and serene, bilingual storyteller and percussionist Mama Edie McLoud Armstrong guides audiences of all ages on a journey to find peace, power and joy within themselves. During monolingual performances or while seamlessly blending stories in Spanish and English, Mama Edie welcomes audiences to broaden their imaginations to create the world that they would rather see, to embrace the multicultural richness within it and love it. Folktales and personal or historical stories of social justice invite audiences to see with new sight and to not be afraid.For all ages.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Walking in Two Worlds: Growing up Indigenous in Turtle Island
description: Madolyn WesawActivist Madolyn Wesaw discusses the complexities of growing up Indigenous in modern America. From erasure in educational systems to misrepresentation in pop culture, learn what we can do to create a more inclusive future for native youth.Madolyn Wesaw is an indigenous activist and mother. A citizen of the Pokagon Band of Potawatomi Indians, she serves Indigenous and other marginalized groups through her work with the American Indian Movement Chapter of Indiana and Kentucky. In addition, Madolyn serves on the Interim Coordinating Committee of the Michiana Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression. She has been involved in projects with the Civil Rights Heritage Center in South Bend, IN., The Kroc Institute for International Peace Studies, and the Newberry Library.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Citywide Special Guest: Maybe Something Beautiful with Chicago Symphony Orchestra
description: Art comes in many forms. Authors make art through their writing. Illustrators make visual art. Chicago Symphony Orchestra makes musical art. Chicago Children's Theatre makes performing art. Storyteller Jasmin Cardenas makes art through her words. All of these artists worked together to make a short movie of beloved children's book, Maybe Something Beautiful, which is about a community making art together. We'll have a mini watch party to enjoy the story and music, and then you can create stick puppets to be able to tell your own story! With just a few common materials, you can make your own puppets as a family. For families with kids from 2 to 12. How to Attend This program will take place on Zoom. ChiTeen Lit Fest goes local to your branch!Benjamin Alire Senz has a rich work of award winning poetry and fiction to explore! Most recently, Aristotle and Dante Dive Into the Waters of the World, the much anticipated sequel to the beloved teen novel, Aristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe.   Join us as we host Benjamin Alire Senz to our ChiTeen Lit Fest author chat.  He will begin the program with a short reading and be interviewed by teen fan, Eric Garcia.   Aristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe was a Printz Honor Book, the Stonewall Award winner, the Pura Belpr Award winner, the Lambda Literary Award winner, and a finalist for the Amelia Elizabeth Walden Award.  The novels cover deep themes of family, coming of age, pride, LGBTQIA relationships, Mexican American heritage, and racism.  The Aristotle and Dante novels and characters have meant much to so many readers.  We are honored to hear from Mr. Senz about his deeply moving and wonderful novels.  This Event takes place on Zoom. Join Independence Branch for an online discussion of feminist fiction and non-fiction!Our second title to be discussed will be Roxane Gay's Bad Feminist.  "This trenchant collection assembles previously published essays and new work by cultural critic and novelist Gay (An Untamed State). Even though she loves pink, feels nostalgic about the Sweet Valley High series, and lets degrading rap lyrics blast from her car stereo, Gay is passionately committed to feminist issues, such as equal opportunity and pay and reproductive freedom. Writing about race, politics, gender, feminism, privilege, and popular media, she highlights how deeply misogyny is embedded in our culture, the careless language used to discuss sexual violence (seen in news reports of sexual assault), Hollywood's tokenistic treatment of race, the trivialization of literature written by women, and the many ways American society fails women and African-Americans. Gay bemoans that fact that role models like Bill Cosby and Don Lemon urge African-Americans to act like ideal citizens while glossing over institutional problems in the education, social welfare, and justice system that exacerbate racism and poverty. Although Gay is aware of her privilege as a middle-class Haitian-American, she doesn't refrain from advising inner-city students to have higher expectations. Whatever her topic, Gay's provocative essays stand out for their bravery, wit, and emotional honesty." ---Publisher's WeeklyHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. YouÕll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Let's Talk About Music: Metal Galaxy
description: Each month the Bucktown Wicker-Park Branch hosts a discussion group where we discuss albums from different eras or styles - one from our choosing and also one from you: BYOA (Bring Your Own Album)! This month we'll discuss Metal Galaxy by Babymetal. Listen to Metal Galaxy on YouTube and come to the event prepared to discuss. Babymetal is a Japanese band that mixes rock, metal, pop, and sometimes electronic music to create their own unique sound dubbed "kawaii metal."If you would like and have the time, listen to Withering to Death by Dir En Grey to see how it compares to Babymetal. We will leave time for anyone who would like to share an album with the group and tell us why itÕs your favorite! Music is beautiful, fun, and best of all: itÕs universal! No matter where youÕre from or how old you are, music is its own language we can all share.Each month the Bucktown Wicker-Park Branch will host an album discussion group where we will discuss albums from different eras or styles. One from our choosing listed below and also one from you: BYOA (Bring Your Own Album)! Listen to the album recommended and be prepared to tell us your favorite tracks and talk about the album as a whole. Then, we will leave time for anyone who would like to share an album with the group and tell us why itÕs your favorite! We can vote to have that be the album for the following month. Each album selected for discussion will most often be available on Hoopla.This month's voted album to discuss is: Mezzanine by Massive Attack. Available here on Hoopla and here on YouTube.Massive Attack are an English electronic band formed in 1988 in Bristol. The Mezzanine album is featured in Rolling Stone's list of the 500 Greatest Albums of All Time. "Some of their most noted songs have featured dramatically atmospheric dynamics, conveyed through either distorted guitar crescendos, lavish orchestral arrangements or prominent, looped/shifting basslines, underpinned by high and exacting production values, involving sometimes copious digital editing and mixing. This style formed a much-emulated style journalists began to dub "trip hop" from the mid-nineties onwards."How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. YouÕll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Reading Beyond the Pages: Becoming a Picture Book Detective
description: Have you ever wondered why picture books look and feel the way they do? The first time you read a picture book, you might have thought it was just a story with some nice pictures. But did you know that every size, shape, color, font, and visual choice was made for a reason?  Each Wednesday from March 16 - April 6, join Miss Rebecca from the Chinatown Branch as she explores the world of picture book art and design. Along the way youÕll become a visual detective and have a chance to show off your new observational skills. If you like art and design, love stories, and can imagine yourself as a sleuth, this program is for you! For kids aged 8-12.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Chicago Public Library cannot collect personal information online from kids 0 to 13. A parent or guardianÕs email address must be used to register. program_name: Advanced Care Planning with Five Wishes
description: One of the greatest gifts you can give your family is to provide guidance on the treatments you would Ð and would not Ð want to receive if you were unable to speak for yourself. This is called advance care planning. Sharing this information with your family and loved ones will provide them with peace of mind, while also assuring that your wishes will be honored.Five Wishes is an easy-to-use legal document that is valid in Illinois and most other states, and is written in everyday language that lets adults plan how they want to be cared for in case they become seriously ill. Five Wishes speaks to a personÕs holistic needs: medical, personal, emotional and spiritual.Presented by Maureen Burns, Community Health Worker, JourneyCare.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Please use the online registration function in this event listing.  YouÕll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. Ever want to be the first to reveal something no one has before? Have you ever wanted to be the first to try out a new technology? Want to become an expert in a subject and use that knowledge to make a positive change in the world? This is the kind of thing we do in Team Stratonauts. Working together as a team of investigators, exploring the unknown with science!

Team Stratonauts is a curiosity-driven cohort of high school-aged science pioneers embedded in Adler’s exploration program, Far Horizons. This year’s program will focus on urban light pollution right here in Chicago. Participants will collaborate with educators, researchers, and engineers to learn what light pollution is and why it’s important, collect light pollution data in their neighborhoods using a series of sensors, and analyze light pollution data.

YOU SHOULD APPLY TO TEAM STRATONAUTS IF YOU’RE:

 - Currently enrolled in high school
 - Interested in creative problem solving and learning through hands-on science exploration
 - Excited to collaborate with peers and STEM professionals to advance new research
 - Available to attend ALL program dates

Due to COVID-19 Team Stratonauts will be a virtual program. We will provide all necessary program materials to selected participants.

Meeting Schedule: Workshops will be held on Saturdays from 10:00 am – 3:00 pm, with a one-hour lunch, on the following dates. 

April 3, 10, 17, 24

May 1, 8, 15, 22

Stipend: Students who successfully complete the workshop series will earn a $300 stipend.

program_name: Spoken Word Academy @ Kelly Hall YMCA
description: The Spoken Word Academy @ Kelly Hall YMCA apprenticeship is a training program for youth to develop creative writing and public speaking skills. Youth choose their own writing topics, featured artists, and event hosts, and they perform at community events, and post their poetry on our program YouTube channel.

Seventh and eighth graders need to master complex reading and math skills, in addition to surviving the social challenges of middle school. Through interactive activities, projects and discussions, Saturday Academy will prepare students to meet these challenges with confidence and independence.

program_name: Comic Book Art Studio @ Washington High School
description: Are you interested in practiced drawing, inking, and coloring comics? Do you enjoy cartoons, superheroes, illustration, and anime, then this is the art studio for you! Create your own character and story and illustrate it with our new program. Learn about the process of creating comics, drawings, and making art from pencil, pen, marker, color pencil. If your inspired and have creative imagination join us at the Comicbook Art Studio.

BLOOM is an art based program with a focus of fine art & street art with a preparation of community organizing. Exploring our creativity allows students to build positive and approaches and projects that cultivate change in the community with recognition to the needs of community and its members.
Firework

Move Me Soul teaches participants about the value of artistic expression and empowerment by integrating participants into their dance company. Teens learn how to produce a performance and create a dance portfolio, and benefit from workshops designed to build confidence and improve performance. Participants are expected to have basic dance skills in order to fully participate in the program.

Teen apprentices in the Hyde Park Art Avengers Illustration program learn about the creative process of a comic book. Teens learn the basics of sketching, drawing, storyboarding, editing and publishing and learn poster, brochure, and product design. Mural painting. Teens compose visual narratives to support compelling stories included in comic books. For a final project teens create original group and individual comic books, as well as a poster, brochure & final product design of their choice.
The new Urban Movement program takes place virtually from the James Jordan Boys & Girls Club and helps teens learn a variety of modern dance styles including Hip Hop and Footwork.

program_name: Set Design and Production for Theater (Downtown Gallery 37)
description: You can learn more about the program and see projects teens have done previously on the program website: www.asmmtx.com This program focuses on the set design process in theatre. Teens will learn how to develop a design idea and how to communicate that idea using Sketchup, a 3D design software. No previous experience with sketchup is required, however having access to a laptop or PC computer is necessary. Additionally, Teens will also have the opportunity to speak with industry professionals and get first hand knowledge on working in theatrical design. By the end of the program teens will have completed two to three design projects, including a set design for a play or musical.

description: This week is STEAM week at Chicago Public Library so join us for a program featuring a science, technology, engineering, art or math theme! program_name: XS Tennis Sports and Leadership Program
description: This program is designed for students to focus on developing leadership skills, effective communication, ethics and learn about sports-related careers including sports broadcasting , team management and the business of sports. Students will participate in skills development workshops, interact with guest speakers and develop their own personal brand.
Students will create 3D modeled versions of iconic characters and props from video games, shows, and movies.

Improvise. Adapt. Overcome!

It’s no question that Shakespeare crafted epic tales that still resonate with high school students today. However, he did die over 400 years ago and times have changed since then. This class will give students the opportunity to create new stories inspired by The Tempest. Use the parts you think are great, change the parts you don’t like. In this class, we dare you to challenge the classics and make Shakespeare your own!

Students will leave the class with:

  1. An understanding of Shakespeare’s original text
  2. An original scene based off the characters/themes of the cannon
  3. The opportunity to create original material in a short time frame
  4. An opportunity to present their work in a live virtual setting

Dates: July 12 - 23 M/T/Th/F

Times: 1:00 PM - 2:15 PM on ZOOM*

PLUS...

Every Wednesday afternoon between June 28th and July 30th, students signed up for ANY of our Summer Shakes classes are invited to OPTIONAL OUTDOOR WEDNESDAYS for an opportunity to come together safely and IN PERSON to enjoy some fun-in-the-sun activities!

[Outdoor locations will all be accessible by public transit and posted at least one week in advance.]

Have you thought about buying a home but have no clue where to start? Join the club! The home buying process does not get covered in school, and a lot more goes into it than you may think. Please join Jenny at the North Pulaski Branch with Kristin Donohue, a realtor with Compass who specializes in working with first time homebuyers. Ms. Donohue will present an overview of each step in the homebuying process, along with directions on where you can get started when the time is right. Alex Margulis, who is the VP of Lending with CrossCountry Mortgage will also join in the conversation to answer your questions. He will cover the ins and outs of the financing portion of buying a home. We will then hold a Q&A, so come prepared with any questions and we can help! How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Sky from Rebirth Garments will show how to measure, pattern, cut and sew their most popular garment, a simple bandeau chest binder. A chest binder is a tight fitting garment that compresses the chest, typically worn by trans masculine folks, nonbinary folks, drag performers, and also anyone who want to minimize the prominence of breast tissue. Sky also discusses how the desire for one of these gender affirming garments as a teen led them to create Rebirth Garments!Materials needed: PowernetSpandex Paper Pattern Weights (soup cans work) ScissorsBinder clips or pinsSewing machine with zig zag stitch or a serger Ruler Measuring tape (or nonstretch string and a ruler) Calculator (or you can do the math longhand)  This video is part of Radical Fit's mini-series on gender affirming garments:Gender affirming garments are clothing items meant to validate the userÕs gender identity and expression, specifically the identities of trans and gender non-conforming people. This includes items such as binders, gaff/tucking underwear, packing underwear, breast forms and more (full definitions linked below). Gender affirmative garments are important because they enable trans and gender non-conforming people to live authentically in their bodies, which supports better mental health (according to The Trevor Project, access to gender affirming clothing can reduce the likelihood of youth suicide attempts: https://www.thetrevorproject.org/survey-2020/?section=Supporting-Transgender-Nonbinary-Youth)We invite you to explore the following resources on the relationship between gender expression and clothing to learn more:Own-voices article: https://www.them.us/story/clothes-shopping-gender-nonconformingIn-depth definitions of gender affirming garments: http://www.phsa.ca/transcarebc/care-support/transitioning/bind-pack-tuck-padMaia KobabeÕs graphic novel memoir Gender QueerA note from Sky: Remember you donÕt have to wear any of these garments in order to be trans or nonbinary. You also donÕt have to experience dysphoria to be trans or nonbinary or to want to wear these garments! These garments should feel celebratory and exciting to wear! This program is led by Sky Cubacub. Sky Cubacub is a non-binary queer and disabled Filipinx human from Chicago, IL. Rebirth Garments is their line of wearables for the full spectrum of gender, size, and ability.How to Attend: This event will take place live on YOUmedia's YouTube page. Radical Fit is a Chicago Public Library YOUmedia program in partnership with Sky Cubacub of Rebirth Garments. This program is funded through Project Next Generation,  an educational technology initiative of Illinois Secretary of State and State Librarian, Jesse White.

Sky from Rebirth Garments will show how to measure, pattern, cut and sew their most popular style of tucking undies! Tucking undies, also known as a gaff, are a garment that can be used to flatten and compress outie bits. Gaffs are typically worn by trans feminine folks, nonbinary folks, drag performers or anyone wanting to minimize outie bits below the belt. Materials needed: PowernetSpandex Paper Pattern Weights (soup cans work) ScissorsBinder clips or pinsSewing machine with zig zag stitch or a serger Ruler Measuring tape (or nonstretch string and a ruler) Calculator (or you can do the math longhand)  This video is part of Radical Fit's mini-series on gender affirming garments:Gender affirming garments are clothing items meant to validate the userÕs gender identity and expression, specifically the identities of trans and gender non-conforming people. Sky from Rebirth Garments will show how to measure, pattern, cut and sew a pocket that accommodates a packer attached to a soft belt that can be worn over any underwear, or under any clothing. A packer is a prosthetic that can be worn in a pocket in underwear or pants that creates a bulge, typically worn by trans masculine folks, nonbinary folks, drag performers and more! Check out EdmundÕs videos on how to make a wool felted packer to put in the pocket! Sky also discusses how the desire for one of these gender affirming garments as a teen led them to create Rebirth Garments and cute anecdotes of coming up with creative solutions as a teen. Materials needed: Spandex or stretch cottonPaper Pattern Weights (soup cans work) ScissorsBinder clips or pinsSewing machine with zig zag stitch or a serger Marking toolRuler Measuring tape (or nonstretch string and a ruler) Calculator (or you can do the math longhand) Optional- 1-2 inch elastic (but can be substituted with spandex) _-_ inch elastic (but can be substituted with spandex) This video is part of Radical Fit's mini-series on gender affirming garments:Gender affirming garments are clothing items meant to validate the userÕs gender identity and expression, specifically the identities of trans and gender non-conforming people. program_name: City of Stories: The Art of Storytelling Learning Circle
description: How would you tell the story of your community? Strengthen your storytelling skills with a learning circle this fall!Do you know you can take an online course at the library in a learning circle? A learning circle is a study group for learners who want to complete online courses, together with others.  This is a free opportunity for adults to learn new skills with others. This season, we will offer virtual learning circle for your convenience. Advance registration is required and free Zoom software is needed for virtual programs. Learning Circles are presented as a six-week courses, and you should plan to attend each of the classes.  Join a six-week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. YouÕll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, and how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required.  Wednesdays, July 13 through August 17, 4:30 pm - 6:00 pm Session 1: July 13 - We are all storytellersSession 2: July 20 - CharacterSession 3: July 27 - Story structureSession 4: August 3 - Visual languageSession 5: August 10 - Film grammarSession 6: August 17- Pitching and feedbackHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. YouÕll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Book Discussion: The Thursday Murder Club
description: Join the Audiobook Discussion Group for a dial-in phone discussion of The Thursday Murder Club Richard Osman.In a peaceful retirement village, four unlikely friends meet weekly to discuss unsolved crimes. When a local developer is found dead with a mysterious photograph left next to the body, the Thursday Murder Club suddenly find themselves in the middle of their first live case. And the bodies begin to pile up.How to Attend This event takes place by phone and especially welcomes patrons with print disabilities. description: The Literature & Language Book Club will discuss Real Life by Brandon Taylor.  "Almost everything about Wallace, an introverted African-American transplant from Alabama, is at odds with the lakeside Midwestern university town where he is working toward a biochem degree. For reasons of self-preservation, Wallace has enforced a wary distance even within his own circle of friends -- some dating each other, some dating women, some feigning straightness. But a series of confrontations with colleagues, and an unexpected encounter with a young straight man, conspire to fracture his defenses, while revealing hidden currents of resentment and desire that threaten the equilibrium of their community." -From the publisherHow to AttendCopies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 7th floor Literature and Language reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605). program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Arsenic and Adobo
description: Join Jenny at North Pulaski for a discussion of Arsenic and Adobo by Mia P. Manansala. "When Lila Macapagal moves back home to recover from a horrible breakup, her life seems to be following all the typical rom-com tropes. She's tasked with saving her Tita Rosie's failing restaurant, and she has to deal with a group of matchmaking aunties who shower her with love and judgment. But when a notoriously nasty food critic (who happens to be her ex-boyfriend) drops dead moments after a confrontation with Lila, her life quickly swerves from a Nora Ephron romp to an Agatha Christie case.With the cops treating her like she's the one and only suspect, and the shady landlord looking to finally kick the Macapagal family out and resell the storefront, Lila's left with no choice but to conduct her own investigation. Armed with the nosy auntie network, her barista best bud, and her trusted Dachshund, Longanisa, Lila takes on this tasty, twisted case and soon finds her own neck on the chopping blockÉ"How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Adult Book Discussion:  How Democracies Die
description: Join the Budlong Woods Branch for a discussion of How Democracies Die by Steven Levitsky and Daniel Ziblatt.    "Drawing on decades of research and a wide range of historical and global examples, from 1930s Europe to contemporary Hungary, Turkey, and Venezuela, to the American South during Jim Crow, Levitsky and Ziblatt show how democracies dieÑand how ours can be saved."  --Publisher"Levitsky and Ziblatt show how democracies have collapsed elsewhere--not just through violent coups, but more commonly (and insidiously) through a gradual slide into authoritarianism. . . . How Democracies Die is a lucid and essential guide to what can happen here." --The New York Times"If this were fiction, the thrills of this book would remind you of the thrills you had when you first read 1984, It Can't Happen Here, The Plot Against America and The Handmaid's Tale. If this were fiction, you could lie in the sand and enjoy the read. But this book is not fiction. And this book is not just about the past. And this book is not just about other countries.Ó  --Tufts Now"Required reading for every American . . . [How Democracies Die] shows the daily slings and arrows that can gradually crush our liberties, without the drama of a revolution or a military coup." --The Philadelphia InquirerSteven Levitsky and Daniel Ziblatt are Professors of Government at Harvard University. Levitsky's research focuses on Latin America and the developing world. He is the author of Competitive Authoritarianism and is the recipient of numerous teaching awards. Ziblatt studies Europe from the nineteenth century to the present. He is the author, most recently, of Conservative Parties and the Birth of Democracy. Both Levitsky and Ziblatt have written for Vox and The New York Times, among other publications.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Only one registration per household is needed. YouÕll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. Join the Clearing Branch for a discussion of Station Eleven by Emily St. John Mandel. Copies of the book are available at the front circulation desk.Kirsten Raymonde will never forget the night Arthur Leander, the famous Hollywood actor, had a heart attack on stage during a production of King Lear. That was the night when a devastating flu pandemic arrived in the city, and within weeks, civilization as we know it came to an end.Twenty years later, Kirsten moves between the settlements of the altered world with a small troupe of actors and musicians. They call themselves The Traveling Symphony, and they have dedicated themselves to keeping the remnants of art and humanity alive. But when they arrive in St. Deborah by the Water, they encounter a violent prophet who will threaten the tiny bandÕs existence. And as the story takes off, moving back and forth in time, and vividly depicting life before and after the pandemic, the strange twist of fate that connects them all will be revealed.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Non-Fiction Book Discussion: The Address Book
description: All are welcome to join a discussion of The Address Book: What Street Addresses Reveal About Identity, Race, Wealth, and Power. "When most people think about street addresses, if they think of them at all, it is in their capacity to ensure that the postman can deliver mail, or a traveler wonÕt get lost. But street addresses were not invented to help you find your way; they were created to find you. In many parts of the world, your address can reveal your race and class.In this wide-ranging and remarkable book, Deirdre Mask looks at the fate of streets named after Martin Luther King Jr., the wayfinding means of ancient Romans, and how Nazis haunt the streets of modern Germany. The flipside of having an address is not having one, and we also see what that means for millions of people today, including those who live in the slums of Kolkata and on the streets of London. Filled with fascinating people and histories, The Address Book illuminates the complex and sometimes hidden stories behind street names and their power to name, to hide, to decide who counts, who doesnÕtÑand why." - from the publisher, St. Martin's PressHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. YouÕll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: On Juneteenth by Annette Gordon-Reed
description: Join Legler Regional as we discuss On Juneteenth by Annette Gordon-Reed.Weaving together American history, dramatic family chronicle, and searing episodes of memoir, Annette Gordon-ReedÕs On Juneteenth provides a historianÕs view of the countryÕs long road to Juneteenth, recounting both its origins in Texas and the enormous hardships that African-Americans have endured in the century since, from Reconstruction through Jim Crow and beyond. All too aware of the stories of cowboys, ranchers, and oilmen that have long dominated the lore of the Lone Star State, Gordon-Reed_herself a Texas native and the descendant of enslaved people brought to Texas as early as the 1820s_forges a new and profoundly truthful narrative of her home state, with implications for us all.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. Only one registration per household is needed. YouÕll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the meeting. By registering for this event, you agree to abide by the Library Use Guidelines.This event uses a third-party website and may be hosted by an organization CPL has partnered with. An effort to encourage “Parent And Child Together” (PACT) Time, the RMP program gives bookbags full of culturally relevant books, games, and arts & crafts to parents/caregivers of children aged 0-5 and facilitates a co-learning circle for parents and their children offering guided family literacy activities. Drop in to experience RMP, and learn more about the 6-week RMP series offered by the UIC Center for Literacy.

#RLDCHI
org_name: University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) Center For Literacy

description: This program is a continuation of the Fall ASM Launch program. We will have the same teens enrolled in this program that were enrolled in ASM Launch - Culinary, ASM Launch - Graphic Design, and ASM Launch - Coding cohorts in the Fall. Teens will check-in with Jeremy Dionisio once / month, complete journal entries 2 times each month, and attend a workshop at least once a month. These will be the 4 touchpoint and make-up the attendance for the program.

The UIC Future Leaders in Business Program is a free summer program in partnership with UIC Business which is designed for rising high school seniors. The goal of this 5-week program is to expose participants to the University of Illinois at Chicago campus and offer comprehensive programming in leadership development and career exploration while receiving academic instruction in the core business areas of accounting, finance, marketing, and management.

program_name: Chicago Opera Theater @ Sarah E. Goode
description: Chicago Opera Theater @ Sarah E. Goode
Advanced Culinary Arts @ Gately

HHW Vocal Arts Ensemble at Gately will focus on music performance from popular and classical genres. Apprentices train in music pedagogy and throughout the program, participants will grow in confidence and perfect their music repertoire.

Join Culinary Arts and learn culinary skills and perfect the basic techniques of cooking and baking. Apprentices receive the foundational training necessary to obtain jobs in the culinary hospitality industry and develop skills that allow them to prepare healthy and sustainable meals for themselves and their families. The program also focuses on cake decorating, table setting, and catering for large groups. For their final presentation, the apprentices prepare a cake display and dinner for the community, family, ASM staff members, and the media.

program_name: Strike!: The Youth Political Theatre Project
description:
In this six-week program, participants act as ambassadors for the theatre and for their communities by collaborating in ensemble-based, youth-driven creation of new virtual theatre pieces in response to political and social events.

Led by Associate Director of Education Quenna Barrett, participants collaborate with their peers to identify a social issue and design theatre-based responses. As part of that process, participants learn their legal rights and the historical context underpinning our current socio-political moment.

description:

For millennia tattooing has served as a unique art form with many intimate and social purposes across the world. But why do we tattoo, scar, or ink our skin? In this workshop series we will engage global tattoo traditions and histories spanning from ancient civilizations to present day meanings of tribal tattooing, and more.  From tattoo folk art influences in the contemporary art world to cultural significances and stereotypes about prison and gang culture tattoos, we will explore our preconceptions about tattoo art and use these comparisons to talk about our own identities, body image, and colonial legacies leading to modern day misconceptions about race.  Throughout this monthly workshop series we will delve into tattoo techniques, styles, and symbols as we craft, sketch, and draw our own tattoo designs. This is the first program for Tattoos & Tribes, a virtual series by Jose Luis Benavides, YOUmedia teen associate at Back of the Yards Branch. How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Creating Mr. Donut Man on the CNC Plasma cutting machine
description:

program_name: Is that Love in the Air? Short Films with ReelAbilities Chicago
description: Reel Abilities Chicago Logo Join us to view online four short films followed by a live conversation shedding new light on dating and relationships with ReelAbilities Chicago. Single (14min.) Kim, who was born with one arm, gets set up on a blind date. When she finally meets Jake, she quickly realizes he also has a physical disability, and she is pissed. An unapologetic perspective on the complexities of being disabled and dating.Second Time (4 min.) A deaf couple chats at a party while everyone else observes the beginning of a beautiful love story. But is the conversation as innocent as it seems?Boldly Go (6 min.) A young gay man is hiding a secret. When a long-term crush tries to seduce him at a party, he is forced to expose the truth.Full Picture (11min.) Santina has been in a wheelchair since she was six years old. With meetings, hangouts, and classes happening virtually due to the coronavirus quarantine, she's experiencing something newÑchoosing when (or if) to disclose her disability.Accessibility: All films will be screened with open captions and audio description. Discussion, questions and answers will have ASL and live captioning.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Register at least 24 hours before the event. program_name: Diamonds in the Rough: the Legacy of Nisei Baseball
description: Join us for a quick peek into the world of Issei American Baseball and the life of pioneering baseball players Kenichi Zenimura and Wally Yonamine.  The first part of the program screens a 34 minute documentary about Zenimura which focuses his time in the Gila River (AZ) concentration camp where he built a baseball field of dreams (On a Pima Indian Reservation).  The movie also covers the post-WWII era when Nisei players returned to Japan to become major stars of the Japanese Professional leagues. These ÔBridge BuildersÕ and American Ambassadors of baseball are the ÔGodfathersÕ to todayÕs all-stars in MLB like Shohei Ohtani, Ichiro, Nomo, Matsui, Murakami, etc. Interviews with Zenimura's widow, and Yonamine are included.  Actor "Pat" Morita is the co-writer and narrator.  Following the screening, Kerry Yo Nakagawa (DIrector/Producer) will give a short talk and respond to questions from the audience. Please join us for a look at a very different aspect of baseball history. Diamonds in the Rough, a product of the Nisei Baseball Research Project (NBRP) (www.niseibaseball.com) was made by Chip Taylor Communications.  This year the NBRP celebrates its 25th Anniversary.  We are pleased to bring you this program in recognition of the work this organization conducts.This program is made possible through the joint efforts of the Asian American/Pacific Islander Cultural Committee and the Social Sciences and History Department of the Chicago Public Library.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Friends of the Gamelan Demonstration and Performance
description: Please join us for a rare free demonstration of Chicago's own gamelan! During this program, Alex Yoffe will provide an explanation of the parts of the gamelan orchestra, a unique and delightful group of instruments typically played in Indonesia.  Alex will also show recordings demonstrating the cultural contexts in which the gamelan is heard in Indonesia.  The program will conclude with a presentation of a shorter-length traditional piece demonstrating how the instruments work together and question period.This promises to be a wonderful, not-to-be-missed experience!  The program will not be recorded, It is a one-time event.Friends of the Gamelan, affectionately know as FROG, traces its roots to the World's Columbian Exposition of 1893, held in Chicago.  One of the many exotic attractions on the Midway Plaisance was the Java Village, complete with a Sundanese gamelan.  Chicago's Field Museum of Natural History was founded to preserve, catalog, and exhibit the many cultural treasures from the Exposition, including the gamelan. In the late 1970s, a group began to meet regularly at the Field Museum to play on those very instruments. FROG formed in 1980 as a not-for-profit educational organization with the purpose of purchasing a Javanese gamelan for pedagogy and performance, to continue the work begun at the Field Museum.Ki Midiyanto, a highly respected gamelan musician and puppeteer (dhalang), assisted FROG in commissioning its bronze gamelan set, Gamelan Sri Sedana, from a gamelan maker in Java.  It arrived in Chicago in 2000.  FROG has been privileged to work with many outstanding Javanese gamelan musicians, including Midiyanto, Sumarsam, Harjito, Wakidi Dwidjomartono, Raharja, Ki Purbo Asmara, Joko Sustrino, and, most recently, Heri Purwanto. FROG also enjoys a close relationship with the Indonesian Consulate-Chicago, which often provides dancers for our performances. FROG has performed at many notable venues, including Pritzker Pavilion at Millennium Park, Chicago World Music Festival at Preston Bradley Hall, and the Field Museum.This program is a joint presentation of the Asian American/Pacific Islander Cultural Committee and the Social Sciences and History Department of the Chicago Public Library.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: City of Stories: The Art of Storytelling Learning Circle
description: How would you tell the story of your community? Strengthen your storytelling skills with a learning circle this fall!Do you know you can take an online course at the library in a learning circle? A learning circle is a study group for learners who want to complete online courses, together with others.  This is a free opportunity for adults to learn new skills with others. This season, we will offer a virtual learning circle for your convenience. Advance registration is required and free Zoom software is needed for virtual programs. Learning Circles are presented as a six-week course, and you should plan to attend each of the classes.  Join a six-week course where you will learn the art of storytelling through exploring the process used at the critically acclaimed Pixar studios. YouÕll join with others to learn how to create characters, the basics of story structure, and how to convey story ideas through visual language, film grammar, and pitching and feedback. This course will take place virtually, and you will need free Zoom software. Registration is required.  Wednesdays, July 13 through August 17, 4:30 pm - 6:00 pm Session 1: July 13 - We are all storytellersSession 2: July 20 - CharacterSession 3: July 27 - Story structureSession 4: August 3 - Visual languageSession 5: August 10 - Film grammarSession 6: August 17- Pitching and feedbackHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: The Tiger: A True Story of Vengeance and Survival
description: Join us as we discuss The Tiger by John Vaillant. Deep in the evergreen woods of the Siberian Taiga, there roams a beast whose prowess and ferocity rivals that of the fictional Great White shark, Jaws. This is The TigerÑa half-ton, eight-feet long, apex predator who has developed a taste for the humans living in this remote wilderness. After a series of maulings, the villagers call for help is answered by Yuri Trush and his team of tiger inspectors. Now the hunt is on and author John Vaillant takes the reader along every step of the way, from the snow-packed tiger tracks winding through the largest boreal forest on Earth to the echoic halls of the Kremlin, looking for answers to questions about deforestation, natural law, and perhaps the most important: Where and when will The Tiger strike next?Copies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 6th floor reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605).How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Adult Book Discussion:  Where Angels Fear to Tread__
description: The Literature & Language Book Club will discuss our Masterpiece title Where Angels Fear to Tread by E.M. Forster. During a trip to Tuscany, the recently widowed Lilia Herriton falls in love with and marries a much younger Italian man. Former brother-in-law Philip goes after her and tries to persuade her to return to England, but when Lilia dies in childbirth the family goes to great length to claim the child. Written in 1905, Forster's first novel is an examination of snobbery and xenophobia in middle class British society.How to AttendCopies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 7th floor Literature and Language reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605). program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Such A Fun Age
description: The Literature & Language Book Club will discuss Such A Fun Age by Kiley Reid. In this electrifying debut, Reid contends with matters of power, race, class, and privilege, weaving storylines that are at times uncomfortable and completely captivating. When a video of 25-year-old African American Mira's humiliating confrontation at a grocery store goes viral, she's forced to confront the inequalities inherent in her relationships with her white boyfriend and white employer, in addition to dealing with her quarter-life crisis. With a current and original plot, well-written, nuanced characters, and lots of juicy showdowns, this novel is impossible to put down.How to AttendCopies of this month's selection will be available 30 days prior to the event at the 7th floor Literature and Language reference desk at Harold Washington Library Center (400 South State Street, Chicago IL, 60605). Roy Glenn will discuss Manipulation and future projects with his readers. Copies of this title will be available at Thurgood Marshall Branch.He is a multi-genre author who is best known as the Master of Urban Suspense for his iconic Mike Black Saga. Always having a very vivid imagination, Roy began making up stories at a very early age; but his passion for writing those stories didn't come until much later in life. "It began with a thought and after a while, the characters and the story became clear to me and began to play over and over like a movie in my mind." He began writing his first novel, Is It a Crime, which became a bestseller and gave birth to the popular character Mike Black, and the Saga began.Other titles in the saga include Queen, The World Is Mine, Rise to the Top, Wrath, Greed, Lust and Boss Of The Family. Roy was born and raised in the Bronx, and currently lives in Jacksonville, Florida where he is working on The Above The Law series.Private DeceptionsWho's Next?How to Attend This event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Author Jacquelin Thomas Discusses The Prodigal Book Series
description: Jacquelin Thomas is an award-winning, best-selling author with 85+ published titles. A few of her recent releases are: Return to Me,  Another Chance With You, and Jezebel. She has published in the romance, womenÕs fiction, inspirational and young adult genres. Her books have garnered several awards, including two EMMA awards, the Romance In Color Reviewers Award, Readers Choice Award and the Atlanta Choice Award in the Religious & Spiritual category. Jacquelin was a 2005 honoree at the Houston Black Film Festival for the movie adaptation of her novel, Hidden Blessings. She was the first recipient to receive the Writers Achievement Award at the North Carolina Book Festival in Winston-Salem. She also received a Lifetime Achievement Award from Romantic Times Magazine. Jacquelin will discuss The Prodigal Series: The Prodigal Husband, Defining Moments, and Unexpected Serenity (available September 30, 2021).How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: Lady in the Lake
description: Join the Budlong Woods Branch for a discussion of Lady in the Lake by Laura Lippman.The New York Times bestselling author returns with a novel set in 1960s Baltimore that combines modern psychological insights with elements of classic noir. In 1966, Baltimore is a city of secrets that everyone seems to know--everyone, that is, except Madeline "Maddie" Schwartz. Last year, she was a happy, even pampered housewife. This year, she's bolted from her marriage of almost twenty years, determined to make good on her youthful ambitions to live a passionate, meaningful life.  Maddie wants to matter, to leave her mark on a swiftly changing world. Drawing on her own secrets, she helps Baltimore police find a murdered girl--assistance that leads to a job at the city's afternoon newspaper, the Star. Working at the newspaper offers Maddie the opportunity to make her name, and she has found just the story to do it: a missing black woman whose body was discovered in the fountain of a city park lake.  --PublisherHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Join the Budlong Woods Branch for a discussion of Anxious People by Fredrik Backman. "Looking at real estate isn't usually a life-or-death situation, but an apartment open house becomes just that when a failed bank robber bursts in and takes a group of strangers hostage. The captives include a recently retired couple who relentlessly hunt down fixer-uppers to avoid the painful truth that they can't fix their own marriage. There's a wealthy bank director who has been too busy to care about anyone else and a young couple who are about to have their first child but can't seem to agree on anything. Add to the mix an eighty-seven-year-old woman who has lived long enough not to be afraid of someone waving a gun in her face, a flustered but still-ready-to-make-a-deal real estate agent, and a mystery man who has locked himself in the apartment's only bathroom, and you've got the worst group of hostages in the world. Each of them carries a lifetime of grievances, hurts, secrets, and passions that are ready to boil over. None of them is entirely who they appear to be. And all of them--the bank robber included--desperately crave some sort of rescue. As the authorities and the media surround the premises, these reluctant allies will reveal surprising truths about themselves and set in motion a chain of events so unexpected that even they can hardly explain what happens next."  --PublisherHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. Join the Budlong Woods Branch for a discussion of The Chaperone by Laura Moriarty. This novel is the basis for the PBS Masterpiece film production directed by Michael Engler and starring Elizabeth McGovern and Haley Lu Richardson.Only a few years before becoming a famous silent-film star and an icon of her generation, a fifteen-year-old Louise Brooks leaves Wichita, Kansas, to study with the prestigious Denishawn School of Dancing in New York. Much to her annoyance, she is accompanied by a thirty-six-year-old chaperone, who is neither mother nor friend. Cora Carlisle, a complicated but traditional woman with her own reasons for making the trip, has no idea what she's in for. Young Louise, already stunningly beautiful and sporting her famous black bob with blunt bangs, is known for her arrogance and her lack of respect for convention. Ultimately, the five weeks they spend together will transform their lives forever.  Drawing on the rich history of the 1920s, '30s, and beyond--from the orphan trains to Prohibition, flappers, and the onset of the Great Depression to the burgeoning movement for equal rights and new opportunities for women--Laura Moriarty's The Chaperone illustrates how rapidly everything, from fashion and hemlines to values and attitudes, was changing at this time and what a vast difference it all made for Louise Brooks, Cora Carlisle, and others like them.  --PublisherHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Science Fiction & Fantasy Book Group: His Master's Voice by Stanislaw Lem
description: All are welcome to join a book discussion of His Master's Voice by Stanislaw Lem (first published in 1968). "By pure chance, scientists detect a signal from space that may be communication from rational beings. How can people of Earth understand this message, knowing nothing about the sendersÑeven whether or not they exist? Written as the memoir of a mathematician who participates in the government project (code name: His Master's Voice) attempting to decode what seems to be a message from outer space, this classic novel shows scientists grappling with fundamental questions about the nature of reality, the confines of knowledge, the limitations of the human mind, and the ethics of military-sponsored scientific research." - from the publisher, MIT PressFor more copies, please ask at the Circulation Desk in the Popular Library at Harold Washington Library Center. How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Non-Fiction Book Discussion - Mad Enchantment: Claude Monet and the Painting of the Water Lilies by Ross King
description: "Claude Monet is perhaps the world's most beloved artist, and among all his creations, the paintings of the water lilies in his garden at Giverny are most famous. Monet intended the water lilies to provide 'an asylum of peaceful meditation.' Yet, as Ross King reveals in his magisterial chronicle of both artist and masterpiece, these beautiful canvases (featured in black and white images throughout, as well as a 16-pg color insert) belie the intense frustration Monet experienced in trying to capture the fugitive effects of light, water, and color. They also reflect the terrible personal torments Monet suffered in the last dozen years of his life.Mad Enchantment tells the full story behind the creation of the Water Lilies, as the horrors of World War I came ever closer to Paris and Giverny and a new generation of younger artists, led by Henri Matisse and Pablo Picasso, were challenging the achievements of Impressionism. By early 1914, French newspapers were reporting that Monet, by then seventy-three, had retired his brushes. He had lost his beloved wife, Alice, and his eldest son, Jean. His famously acute vision--what Paul Cezanne called 'the most prodigious eye in the history of painting' --was threatened by cataracts. And yet, despite ill health, self-doubt, and advancing age, Monet began painting again on a more ambitious scale than ever before.Linking great artistic achievement to the personal and historical dramas unfolding around it, Ross King presents the most intimate and revealing portrait of an iconic figure in world culture." - from Bloomsbury PublishingHow to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Adult Book Discussion: The Color of Food: Race, Resilience and Farming
description: Jeffery Manor will lead a discussion of The Color of Food: Race, Resilience and Farming by Natasha Bowens.By recognizing the critical issues that lie at the intersection of race and food, this stunning collection of portraits and stories challenges the status quo of agrarian identity. Author, photographer, and biracial farmer Natasha Bowens's quest to explore her own roots in the soil leads her to unearth a larger story, weaving together the seemingly forgotten history of agriculture for people of color, the issues they face today, and the culture and resilience they bring to food and farming.Copies are available for checkout or you can place a hold on a circulating copy.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom. program_name: Better with a Beverage Discussion: Homeland Elegies
description: Relax, enjoy a beverage and read.Over the course of the month, read Homeland Elegies by Ayad Akhtar and aim to try at least one beverage from a Chicago-based institution of your choice while you read.  At the end of the month, we will meet on Zoom to discuss the book and any interesting beverages you tried. Feel free to join the discussion BYOB-style."This achingly intimate novel-cum-memoir from Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Akhtar (Disgraced) searingly explores the existential questions consuming immigrants in the United States, a task he began with his debut novel, American Dervish. They're asked where their loyalties lie and told "Go back where you came from," even if, like our narrator, they are born here." - Library JournalThis event is hosted by Jacob from the Richard M. program_name: 'Steenth Street: Alice Dunbar-Nelson's Stories of Black Childhood
description: Come learn about a project to recover a short story collection written in the 1890s by Black author, activist, and educator Alice Dunbar-Nelson. Inspired by her work teaching kindergarteners at the White Rose Mission in New York City, Dunbar-Nelson wrote a series of wry short stories featuring the youngest residents of an urban neighborhood targeted for uplift by Progressive-era reformers. ÒThe Annals of ÕSteenth Street,Ó as Dunbar-Nelson titled the planned collection, chronicles a vibrant, working poor community. Although the stories never saw print as a group, scholars recently discovered that Dunbar-Nelson published six of them in 1900 and 1901 in The Chicago Daily News, a metropolitan daily with a broad readership. This is the first in a series of public forums about Dunbar-Nelson's story collection and the challenges of recovering Black-authored literature.Participants will include Denise Burgher, doctoral candidate, University of Delaware; Brigitte Fielder, associate professor, University of Wisconsin-Madison; and Jean Lutes, Luckow Family Endowed Chair in English Literature, Villanova University.How to AttendThis event takes place on Zoom.
